title: 孟子
source: Chinese Text Project (ctext.org) - James Legge translation

passages.zh: 滕文公為世子，將之楚，過宋而見孟子。
passages.en: When the prince, afterwards duke Wen of Teng, had to go to Chu, he went by way of Song, and visited Mencius.

passages.zh: 孟子道性善，言必稱堯舜。
passages.en: Mencius discoursed to him how the nature of man is good, and when speaking, always made laudatory reference to Yao and Shun.

passages.zh: 世子自楚反，復見孟子。
passages.en: When the prince was returning from Chu, he again visited Mencius.

passages.zh: 孟子曰：「世子疑吾言乎？
passages.en: Mencius said to him, 'Prince, do you doubt my words?

passages.zh: 夫道一而已矣。
passages.en: The path is one, and only one.

passages.zh: 成覸謂齊景公曰：『彼丈夫也，我丈夫也，吾何畏彼哉？』
passages.en: Cheng Gan said to duke Jing of Qi, "They were men. I am a man. Why should I stand in awe of them?"

passages.zh: 顏淵曰：『舜何人也？予何人也？有為者亦若是。』
passages.en: Yan Yuan said, "What kind of man was Shun? What kind of man am I? He who exerts himself will also become such as he was."

passages.zh: 公明儀曰：『文王我師也，周公豈欺我哉？』
passages.en: Gong Ming Yi said, "King Wen is my teacher. How should the duke of Zhou deceive me by those words?"

passages.zh: 今滕，絕長補短，將五十里也，猶可以為善國。
passages.en: Now, Teng, taking its length with its breadth, will amount, I suppose, to fifty li. It is small, but still sufficient to make a good State.

passages.zh: 《書》曰：『若藥不瞑眩，厥疾不瘳。』」
passages.en: It is said in the Book of History, "If medicine do not raise a commotion in the patient, his disease will not be cured by it."'

passages.zh: 滕定公薨。
passages.en: When the duke Ding of Teng died,

passages.zh: 世子謂然友曰：「昔者孟子嘗與我言於宋，於心終不忘。
passages.en: the prince said to Ran You, 'Formerly, Mencius spoke with me in Song, and in my mind I have never forgotten his words.

passages.zh: 今也不幸至於大故，吾欲使子問於孟子，然後行事。」
passages.en: Now, alas! this great duty to my father devolves upon me; I wish to send you to ask the advice of Mencius, and then to proceed to its various services'

passages.zh: 然友之鄒問於孟子。
passages.en: Ran You accordingly proceeded to Zou, and consulted Mencius.

passages.zh: 孟子曰：「不亦善乎！
passages.en: Mencius said, 'Is this not good?

passages.zh: 親喪固所自盡也。
passages.en: In discharging the funeral duties to parents, men indeed feel constrained to do their utmost.

passages.zh: 曾子曰：『生事之以禮；死葬之以禮，祭之以禮，可謂孝矣。』
passages.en: The philosopher Zeng said, "When parents are alive, they should be served according to propriety; when they are dead, they should be buried according to propriety; and they should be sacrificed to according to propriety - this may be called filial piety."

passages.zh: 諸侯之禮，吾未之學也；雖然，吾嘗聞之矣。
passages.en: The ceremonies to be observed by the princes I have not learned, but I have heard these points:

passages.zh: 三年之喪，齊疏之服，飦粥之食，自天子達於庶人，三代共之。」
passages.en: that the three years' mourning, the garment of coarse cloth with its lower edge even, and the eating of congee, were equally prescribed by the three dynasties, and binding on all, from the sovereign to the mass of the people.'

passages.zh: 然友反命，定為三年之喪。
passages.en: Ran You reported the execution of his commission, and the prince determined that the three years' mourning should be observed.

passages.zh: 父兄百官皆不欲，曰：「吾宗國魯先君莫之行，吾先君亦莫之行也，至於子之身而反之，不可。
passages.en: His aged relatives, and the body of the officers, did not wish that it should be so, and said, 'The former princes of Lu, that kingdom which we honour, have, none of them, observed this practice, neither have any of our own former princes observed it. For you to act contrary to their example is not proper.

passages.zh: 且志曰：『喪祭從先祖。』」
passages.en: Moreover, the History says, "In the observances of mourning and sacrifice, ancestors are to be followed," meaning that they received those things from a proper source to hand them down.'

passages.zh: 曰：「吾有所受之也。」
passages.en: The prince said again to Ran You,

passages.zh: 謂然友曰：「吾他日未嘗學問，好馳馬試劍。
passages.en: 'Hitherto, I have not given myself to the pursuit of learning, but have found my pleasure in horsemanship and sword-exercise,

passages.zh: 今也父兄百官不我足也，恐其不能盡於大事，子為我問孟子。」
passages.en: and now I don't come up to the wishes of my aged relatives and the officers. I am afraid I may not be able to discharge my duty in the great business that I have entered on; do you again consult Mencius for me.'

passages.zh: 然友復之鄒問孟子。
passages.en: On this, Ran You went again to Zou, and consulted Mencius.

passages.zh: 孟子曰：「然。不可以他求者也。
passages.en: Mencius said, 'It is so, but he may not seek a remedy in others, but only in himself.

passages.zh: 孔子曰：『君薨，聽於冢宰。歠粥，面深墨。即位而哭，百官有司，莫敢不哀，先之也。』
passages.en: Confucius said, "When a prince dies, his successor entrusts the administration to the prime minister. He sips the congee. His face is of a deep black. He approaches the place of mourning, and weeps. Of all the officers and inferior ministers there is not one who will presume not to join in the lamentation, he setting them this example.

passages.zh: 上有好者，下必有甚焉者矣。
passages.en: What the superior loves, his inferiors will be found to love exceedingly.

passages.zh: 『君子之德，風也；小人之德，草也。草尚之風必偃。』
passages.en: The relation between superiors and inferiors is like that between the wind and grass. The grass must bend when the wind blows upon it."

passages.zh: 是在世子。」
passages.en: The business depends on the prince.'

passages.zh: 然友反命。
passages.en: Ran You returned with this answer to his commission,

passages.zh: 世子曰：「然。是誠在我。」
passages.en: and the prince said, 'It is so. The matter does indeed depend on me.'

passages.zh: 五月居廬，未有命戒。
passages.en: So for five months he dwelt in the shed, without issuing an order or a caution.

passages.zh: 百官族人可謂曰知。
passages.en: All the officers and his relatives said, 'He may be said to understand the ceremonies.'

passages.zh: 及至葬，四方來觀之，顏色之戚，哭泣之哀，弔者大悅。
passages.en: When the time of interment arrived, they came from all quarters of the State to witness it. Those who had come from other States to condole with him, were greatly pleased with the deep dejection of his countenance and the mournfulness of his wailing and weeping.

passages.zh: 滕文公問為國。
passages.en: The duke Wen of Teng asked Mencius about the proper way of governing a kingdom.

passages.zh: 孟子曰：「民事不可緩也。
passages.en: Mencius said, 'The business of the people may not be remissly attended to.

passages.zh: 《詩》云：『晝爾于茅，宵爾索綯；亟其乘屋，其始播百穀。』
passages.en: It is said in the Book of Poetry, "In the day-light go and gather the grass, And at night twist your ropes; Then get up quickly on the roofs; Soon must we begin sowing again the grain."

passages.zh: 民之為道也，有恆產者有恆心，無恆產者無恆心。
passages.en: The way of the people is this: If they have a certain livelihood, they will have a fixed heart; if they have not a certain livelihood, they have not a fixed heart.

passages.zh: 苟無恆心，放辟邪侈，無不為已。
passages.en: If they have not a fixed heart, there is nothing which they will not do in the way of self-abandonment, of moral deflection, of depravity, and of wild license.

passages.zh: 及陷乎罪，然後從而刑之，是罔民也。
passages.en: When they have thus been involved in crime, to follow them up and punish them - this is to entrap the people.

passages.zh: 焉有仁人在位，罔民而可為也？
passages.en: How can such a thing as entrapping the people be done under the rule of a benevolent man?

passages.zh: 是故賢君必恭儉禮下，取於民有制。
passages.en: Therefore, a ruler who is endowed with talents and virtue will be gravely complaisant and economical, showing a respectful politeness to his ministers, and taking from the people only in accordance with regulated limits.

passages.zh: 陽虎曰：『為富不仁矣，為仁不富矣。』
passages.en: Yang Hu said, "He who seeks to be rich will not be benevolent. He who wishes to be benevolent will not be rich."

passages.zh: 「夏后氏五十而貢，殷人七十而助，周人百畝而徹，其實皆什一也。
passages.en: 'The sovereign of the Xia dynasty enacted the fifty mu allotment, and the payment of a tax. The founder of the Yin enacted the seventy mu allotment, and the system of mutual aid. The founder of the Zhou enacted the hundred mu allotment, and the share system. In reality, what was paid in all these was a tithe.

passages.zh: 徹者，徹也；助者，藉也。
passages.en: The share system means mutual division. The aid system means mutual dependence.

passages.zh: 龍子曰：『治地莫善於助，莫不善於貢。
passages.en: Long said, "For regulating the lands, there is no better system than that of mutual aid, and none which is not better than that of taxing.

passages.zh: 貢者校數歲之中以為常。
passages.en: By the tax system, the regular amount was fixed by taking the average of several years.

passages.zh: 樂歲，粒米狼戾，多取之而不為虐，則寡取之；凶年，糞其田而不足，則必取盈焉。
passages.en: In good years, when the grain lies about in abundance, much might be taken without its being oppressive, and the actual exaction would be small. But in bad years, the produce being not sufficient to repay the manuring of the fields, this system still requires the taking of the full amount.

passages.zh: 為民父母，使民盻盻然，將終歲勤動，不得以養其父母，又稱貸而益之。使老稚轉乎溝壑，惡在其為民父母也？』
passages.en: When the parent of the people causes the people to wear looks of distress, and, after the whole year's toil, yet not to be able to nourish their parents, so that they proceed to borrowing to increase their means, till the old people and children are found lying in the ditches and water-channels - where, in such a case, is his parental relation to the people?"

passages.zh: 夫世祿，滕固行之矣。
passages.en: As to the system of hereditary salaries, that is already observed in Teng.

passages.zh: 《詩》云：『雨我公田，遂及我私。』惟助為有公田。
passages.en: It is said in the Book of Poetry, "May the rain come down on our public field, And then upon our private fields!" It is only in the system of mutual aid that there is a public field,

passages.zh: 由此觀之，雖周亦助也。
passages.en: and from this passage we perceive that even in the Zhou dynasty this system has been recognised.

passages.zh: 「設為庠序學校以教之：庠者，養也；校者，教也；序者，射也。
passages.en: 'Establish Xiang, Xu, Xue, and Xiao, all those educational institutions, for the instruction of the people. The name Xiang indicates nourishing as its object; Xiao, indicates teaching; and Xu indicates archery.

passages.zh: 夏曰校，殷曰序，周曰庠，學則三代共之，皆所以明人倫也。
passages.en: By the Xia dynasty the name Xiao was used; by the Yin, that of Xu; and by the Zhou, that of Xiang. As to the Xue, they belonged to the three dynasties, and by that name. The object of them all is to illustrate the human relations.

passages.zh: 人倫明於上，小民親於下。
passages.en: When those are thus illustrated by superiors, kindly feeling will prevail among the inferior people below.

passages.zh: 有王者起，必來取法，是為王者師也。
passages.en: Should a real sovereign arise, he will certainly come and take an example from you; and thus you will be the teacher of the true sovereign.

passages.zh: 《詩》云『周雖舊邦，其命惟新』，文王之謂也。
passages.en: It is said in the Book of Poetry, "Although Zhou was an old country, It received a new destiny." That is said with reference to king Wen.

passages.zh: 子力行之，亦以新子之國。」
passages.en: Do you practise those things with vigour, and you also will by them make new your kingdom.'

passages.zh: 使畢戰問井地。
passages.en: The duke afterwards sent Bi Zhan to consult Mencius about the nine-squares system of dividing the land.

passages.zh: 孟子曰：「子之君將行仁政，選擇而使子，子必勉之！
passages.en: Mencius said to him, 'Since your prince, wishing to put in practice a benevolent government, has made choice of you and put you into this employment, you must exert yourself to the utmost.

passages.zh: 夫仁政，必自經界始。
passages.en: Now, the first thing towards a benevolent government must be to lay down the boundaries.

passages.zh: 經界不正，井地不鈞，穀祿不平。
passages.en: If the boundaries be not defined correctly, the division of the land into squares will not be equal, and the produce available for salaries will not be evenly distributed.

passages.zh: 是故暴君汙吏必慢其經界。
passages.en: On this account, oppressive rulers and impure ministers are sure to neglect this defining of the boundaries.

passages.zh: 經界既正，分田制祿可坐而定也。
passages.en: When the boundaries have been defined correctly, the division of the fields and the regulation of allowances may be determined by you, sitting at your ease.

passages.zh: 夫滕壤地褊小，將為君子焉，將為野人焉。
passages.en: Although the territory of Teng is narrow and small, yet there must be in it men of a superior grade, and there must be in it country-men.

passages.zh: 無君子莫治野人，無野人莫養君子。
passages.en: If there were not men of a superior grade, there would be none to rule the country-men. If there were not country-men, there would be none to support the men of superior grade.

passages.zh: 請野九一而助，國中什一使自賦。
passages.en: I would ask you, in the remoter districts, observing the nine-squares division, to reserve one division to be cultivated on the system of mutual aid, and in the more central parts of the kingdom, to make the people pay for themselves a tenth part of their produce.

passages.zh: 卿以下必有圭田，圭田五十畝。餘夫二十五畝。
passages.en: From the highest officers down to the lowest, each one must have his holy field, consisting of fifty mu. Let the supernumerary males have their twenty-five mu.

passages.zh: 死徙無出鄉，鄉田同井。
passages.en: On occasions of death, or removal from one dwelling to another, there will be no quitting the district. In the fields of a district, those who belong to the same nine squares render all friendly offices to one another in their going out and coming in,

passages.zh: 出入相友，守望相助，疾病相扶持，則百姓親睦。
passages.en: aid one another in keeping watch and ward, and sustain one another in sickness. Thus the people are brought to live in affection and harmony.

passages.zh: 方里而井，井九百畝，其中為公田。
passages.en: A square li covers nine squares of land, which nine squares contain nine hundred mu. The central square is the public field,

passages.zh: 八家皆私百畝，同養公田。
passages.en: and eight families, each having its private hundred mu, cultivate in common the public field.

passages.zh: 公事畢，然後敢治私事，所以別野人也。
passages.en: And not till the public work is finished, may they presume to attend to their private affairs. This is the way by which the country-men are distinguished from those of a superior grade.

passages.zh: 此其大略也。若夫潤澤之，則在君與子矣。」
passages.en: Those are the great outlines of the system. Happily to modify and adapt it depends on the prince and you.'

passages.zh: 有為神農之言者許行，自楚之滕，踵門而告文公曰：「遠方之人聞君行仁政，願受一廛而為氓。」
passages.en: There came from Chu to Teng one Xu Xing, who gave out that he acted according to the words of Shen Nong. Coming right to his gate, he addressed the duke Wen, saying, 'A man of a distant region, I have heard that you, Prince, are practising a benevolent government, and I wish to receive a site for a house, and to become one of your people.'

passages.zh: 文公與之處，其徒數十人，皆衣褐，捆屨、織席以為食。
passages.en: The duke Wen gave him a dwelling-place. His disciples, amounting to several tens, all wore clothes of haircloth, and made sandals of hemp and wove mats for a living.

passages.zh: 陳良之徒陳相與其弟辛，負耒耜而自宋之滕，曰：「聞君行聖人之政，是亦聖人也，願為聖人氓。」
passages.en: At the same time, Chen Xiang, a disciple of Chen Liang, and his younger brother, Xin, with their plough-handles and shares on their backs, came from Song to Teng, saying, 'We have heard that you, Prince, are putting into practice the government of the ancient sages, showing that you are likewise a sage. We wish to become the subjects of a sage.'

passages.zh: 陳相見許行而大悅，盡棄其學而學焉。
passages.en: When Chen Xiang saw Xu Xing, he was greatly pleased with him, and, abandoning entirely whatever he had learned, became his disciple.

passages.zh: 陳相見孟子，道許行之言曰：「滕君，則誠賢君也；雖然，未聞道也。
passages.en: Having an interview with Mencius, he related to him with approbation the words of Xu Xing to the following effect: 'The prince of Teng is indeed a worthy prince. He has not yet heard, however, the real doctrines of antiquity.

passages.zh: 賢者與民並耕而食，饔飧而治。
passages.en: Now, wise and able princes should cultivate the ground equally and along with their people, and eat the fruit of their labour. They should prepare their own meals, morning and evening, while at the same time they carry on their government.

passages.zh: 今也滕有倉廩府庫，則是厲民而以自養也，惡得賢？」
passages.en: But now, the prince of T'ang has his granaries, treasuries, and arsenals, which is an oppressing of the people to nourish himself. How can he be deemed a real worthy prince?'

passages.zh: 孟子曰：「許子必種粟而後食乎？」
passages.en: Mencius said,'I suppose that Xu Xing sows grain and eats the produce. Is it not so?'
'It is so,' was the answer.

passages.zh: 「許子必織布而後衣乎？」
passages.en: 'I suppose also he weaves cloth, and wears his own manufacture. Is it not so?'

passages.zh: 曰：「否。許子衣褐。」
passages.en: 'No. Xu wears clothes of haircloth.'

passages.zh: 「許子冠乎？」
passages.en: 'Does he wear a cap?'
'He wears a cap.'

passages.zh: 曰：「奚冠？」
passages.en: 'What kind of cap?'

passages.zh: 曰：「冠素。」
passages.en: 'A plain cap.'

passages.zh: 曰：「自織之與？」
passages.en: 'Is it woven by himself?'

passages.zh: 曰：「否。以粟易之。」
passages.en: 'No. He gets it in exchange for grain.'

passages.zh: 曰：「許子奚為不自織？」
passages.en: 'Why does Xu not weave it himself?'

passages.zh: 曰：「害於耕。」
passages.en: 'That would injure his husbandry.'

passages.zh: 曰：「許子以釜甑爨，以鐵耕乎？」
passages.en: 'Does Xu cook his food in boilers and earthenware pans, and does he plough with an iron share?'
'Yes.'

passages.zh: 「自為之與？」
passages.en: 'Does he make those articles himself?'

passages.zh: 曰：「否。以粟易之。」
passages.en: 'No. He gets them in exchange for grain.'

passages.zh: 「以粟易械器者，不為厲陶冶；陶冶亦以其械器易粟者，豈為厲農夫哉？
passages.en: Mencius then said, 'The getting those various articles in exchange for grain, is not oppressive to the potter and the founder, and the potter and the founder in their turn, in exchanging their various articles for grain, are not oppressive to the husbandman. How should such a thing be supposed?

passages.zh: 且許子何不為陶冶。舍皆取諸其宮中而用之？
passages.en: And moreover, why does not Xu act the potter and founder, supplying himself with the articles which he uses solely from his own establishment?

passages.zh: 何為紛紛然與百工交易？何許子之不憚煩？」
passages.en: Why does he go confusedly dealing and exchanging with the handicraftsmen? Why does he not spare himself so much trouble?'

passages.zh: 曰：「百工之事，固不可耕且為也。」
passages.en: Chen Xiang replied, 'The business of the handicraftsman can by no means be carried on along with the business of husbandry.'

passages.zh: 「然則治天下獨可耕且為與？
passages.en: Mencius resumed, 'Then, is it the government of the kingdom which alone can be carried on along with the practice of husbandry?

passages.zh: 有大人之事，有小人之事。
passages.en: Great men have their proper business, and little men have their proper business.

passages.zh: 且一人之身，而百工之所為備。如必自為而後用之，是率天下而路也。
passages.en: Moreover, in the case of any single individual, whatever articles he can require are ready to his hand, being produced by the various handicraftsmen - if he must first make them for his own use, this way of doing would keep all the people running about upon the roads.

passages.zh: 故曰：或勞心，或勞力；勞心者治人，勞力者治於人；治於人者食人，治人者食於人：天下之通義也。
passages.en: Hence, there is the saying, "Some labour with their minds, and some labour with their strength. Those who labour with their minds govern others; those who labour with their strength are governed by others. Those who are governed by others support them; those who govern others are supported by them." This is a principle universally recognised.

passages.zh: 「當堯之時，天下猶未平，洪水橫流，氾濫於天下。
passages.en: 'In the time of Yao, when the world had not yet been perfectly reduced to order, the vast waters, flowing out of their channels, made a universal inundation.

passages.zh: 草木暢茂，禽獸繁殖，五穀不登，禽獸偪人。
passages.en: Vegetation was luxuriant, and birds and beasts swarmed. The various kinds of grain could not be grown. The birds and beasts pressed upon men.

passages.zh: 獸蹄鳥跡之道，交於中國。
passages.en: The paths marked by the feet of beasts and prints of birds crossed one another throughout the Middle Kingdom.

passages.zh: 堯獨憂之，舉舜而敷治焉。
passages.en: To Yao alone this caused anxious sorrow. He raised Shun to office, and measures to regulate the disorder were set forth.

passages.zh: 舜使益掌火，益烈山澤而焚之，禽獸逃匿。
passages.en: Shun committed to Yi the direction of the fire to be employed, and Yi set fire to, and consumed, the forests and vegetation on the mountains and in the marshes, so that the birds and beasts fled away to hide themselves.

passages.zh: 禹疏九河，瀹濟漯，而注諸海；決汝漢，排淮泗，而注之江，然後中國可得而食也。
passages.en: Yu separated the nine streams, cleared the courses of the Ji and Ta, and led them all to the sea. He opened a vent also for the Ru and Han, and regulated the course of the Huai and Si, so that they all flowed into the Jiang. When this was done, it became possible for the people of the Middle Kingdom to cultivate the ground and get food for themselves.

passages.zh: 當是時也，禹八年於外，三過其門而不入，雖欲耕，得乎？
passages.en: During that time, Yu was eight years away from his home, and though he thrice passed the door of it, he did not enter. Although he had wished to cultivate the ground, could he have done so?

passages.zh: 后稷教民稼穡。樹藝五穀，五穀熟而民人育。
passages.en: The Minister of Agriculture taught the people to sow and reap, cultivating the five kinds of grain. When the five kinds of grain were brought to maturity, the people all obtained a subsistence.

passages.zh: 人之有道也，飽食、煖衣、逸居而無教，則近於禽獸。
passages.en: But men possess a moral nature; and if they are well fed, warmly clad, and comfortably lodged, without being taught at the same time, they become almost like the beasts.

passages.zh: 聖人有憂之，使契為司徒，教以人倫：父子有親，君臣有義，夫婦有別，長幼有序，朋友有信。
passages.en: This was a subject of anxious solicitude to the sage Shun, and he appointed Xie to be the Minister of Instruction, to teach the relations of humanity: how, between father and son, there should be affection; between sovereign and minister, righteousness; between husband and wife, attention to their separate functions; between old and young, a proper order; and between friends, fidelity.

passages.zh: 放勳曰：『勞之來之，匡之直之，輔之翼之，使自得之，又從而振德之。』
passages.en: The high meritorious sovereign said to him, "Encourage them; lead them on; rectify them; straighten them; help them; give them wings - thus causing them to become possessors of themselves. Then follow this up by stimulating them, and conferring benefits on them."

passages.zh: 聖人之憂民如此，而暇耕乎？
passages.en: When the sages were exercising their solicitude for the people in this way, had they leisure to cultivate the ground?

passages.zh: 「堯以不得舜為己憂，舜以不得禹、皋陶為己憂。
passages.en: 'What Yao felt giving him anxiety was the not getting Shun. What Shun felt giving him anxiety was the not getting Yu and Gao Yao.

passages.zh: 夫以百畝之不易為己憂者，農夫也。
passages.en: But he whose anxiety is about his hundred mu not being properly cultivated, is a mere husbandman.

passages.zh: 分人以財謂之惠，教人以善謂之忠，為天下得人者謂之仁。
passages.en: The imparting by a man to others of his wealth, is called "kindness." The teaching others what is good, is called "the exercise of fidelity." The finding a man who shall benefit the kingdom, is called "benevolence."

passages.zh: 是故以天下與人易，為天下得人難。
passages.en: Hence to give the throne to another man would be easy; to find a man who shall benefit the kingdom is difficult.

passages.zh: 孔子曰：『大哉堯之為君！惟天為大，惟堯則之，蕩蕩乎民無能名焉！君哉舜也！巍巍乎有天下而不與焉！』
passages.en: Confucius said, "Great indeed was Yao as a sovereign. It is only Heaven that is great, and only Yao corresponded to it. How vast was his virtue! The people could find no name for it. Princely indeed was Shun! How majestic was he, having possession of the kingdom, and yet seeming as if it were nothing to him!"

passages.zh: 堯舜之治天下，豈無所用其心哉？亦不用於耕耳。
passages.en: In their governing the kingdom, were there no subjects on which Yao and Shun employed their minds? There were subjects, only they did not employ their minds on the cultivation of the ground.

passages.zh: 「吾聞用夏變夷者，未聞變於夷者也。
passages.en: 'I have heard of men using the doctrines of our great land to change barbarians, but I have never yet heard of any being changed by barbarians.

passages.zh: 陳良，楚產也。悅周公、仲尼之道，北學於中國。
passages.en: Chen Liang was a native of Chu. Pleased with the doctrines of Zhou Gong and Zhong Ni, he came northwards to the Middle Kingdom and studied them.

passages.zh: 北方之學者，未能或之先也。彼所謂豪傑之士也。
passages.en: Among the scholars of the northern regions, there was perhaps no one who excelled him. He was what you call a scholar of high and distinguished qualities.

passages.zh: 子之兄弟事之數十年，師死而遂倍之。
passages.en: You and your brother followed him some tens of years, and when your master died, you forthwith turned away from him.

passages.zh: 昔者孔子沒，三年之外，門人治任將歸，入揖於子貢，相向而哭，皆失聲，然後歸。
passages.en: Formerly, when Confucius died, after three vears had elapsed, his disciples collected their baggage, and prepared to return to their several homes. But on entering to take their leave of Zi Gong, as they looked towards one another, they wailed, till they all lost their voices. After this they returned to their homes,

passages.zh: 子貢反，築室於場，獨居三年，然後歸。
passages.en: but Zi Gong went back, and built a house for himself on the altar-ground, where he lived alone other three years, before he returned home.

passages.zh: 他日，子夏、子張、子游以有若似聖人，欲以所事孔子事之，彊曾子。
passages.en: On another occasion, Zi Xia, Zi Zhang, and Zi You, thinking that You Ruo resembled the sage, wished to render to him the same observances which they had rendered to Confucius. They tried to force the disciple Zeng to join with them,

passages.zh: 曾子曰：『不可。江漢以濯之，秋陽以暴之，皜皜乎不可尚已。』
passages.en: but he said, "This may not be done. What has been washed in the waters of the Jiang and Han, and bleached in the autumn sun - how glistening is it! Nothing can be added to it."

passages.zh: 今也南蠻鴃舌之人，非先王之道，子倍子之師而學之，亦異於曾子矣。
passages.en: Now here is this shrike-tongued barbarian of the south, whose doctrines are not those of the ancient kings. You turn away from your master and become his disciple. Your conduct is different indeed from that of the philosopher Zeng.

passages.zh: 吾聞出於幽谷遷于喬木者，末聞下喬木而入於幽谷者。
passages.en: I have heard of birds leaving dark valleys to remove to lofty trees, but I have not heard of their descending from lofty trees to enter into dark valleys.

passages.zh: 《魯頌》曰：『戎狄是膺，荊舒是懲。』周公方且膺之，子是之學，亦為不善變矣。」
passages.en: In the Praise-songs of Lu it is said, "He smote the barbarians of the west and the north, He punished Jing and Shu." Thus Zhou Gong would be sure to smite them, and you become their disciple again; it appears that your change is not good.'

passages.zh: 「從許子之道，則市賈不貳，國中無偽。
passages.en: Chen Xiang said, 'If Xu's doctrines were followed, then there would not be two prices in the market, nor any deceit in the kingdom.

passages.zh: 雖使五尺之童適市，莫之或欺。
passages.en: If a boy of five cubits were sent to the market, no one would impose on him;

passages.zh: 布帛長短同，則賈相若；麻縷絲絮輕重同，則賈相若；五穀多寡同，則賈相若；屨大小同，則賈相若。」
passages.en: linen and silk of the same length would be of the same price. So it would be with bundles of hemp and silk, being of the same weight; with the different kinds of grain, being the same in quantity; and with shoes which were of the same size.'

passages.zh: 曰：「夫物之不齊，物之情也；或相倍蓰，或相什伯，或相千萬。
passages.en: Mencius replied, 'It is the nature of things to be of unequal quality. Some are twice, some five times, some ten times, some a hundred times, some a thousand times, some ten thousand times as valuable as others.

passages.zh: 子比而同之，是亂天下也。
passages.en: If you reduce them all to the same standard, that must throw the kingdom into confusion.

passages.zh: 巨屨小屨同賈，人豈為之哉？
passages.en: If large shoes and small shoes were of the same price, who would make them?

passages.zh: 從許子之道，相率而為偽者也，惡能治國家？」
passages.en: For people to follow the doctrines of Xu, would be for them to lead one another on to practise deceit. How can they avail for the government of a State?'

passages.zh: 墨者夷之，因徐辟而求見孟子。
passages.en: The Mohist, Yi Zhi, sought, through Xu Bi, to see Mencius.

passages.zh: 孟子曰：「吾固願見，今吾尚病，病愈，我且往見，夷子不來！」
passages.en: Mencius said, 'I indeed wish to see him, but at present I am still unwell. When I am better, I will myself go and see him. He need not come here again.'

passages.zh: 他日又求見孟子。
passages.en: Next day, Yi Zhi again sought to see Mencius.

passages.zh: 孟子曰：「吾今則可以見矣。不直，則道不見；我且直之。
passages.en: Mencius said, 'To-day I am able to see him. But if I do not correct his errors, the true principles will not be fully evident. Let me first correct him.

passages.zh: 吾聞夷子墨者。墨之治喪也，以薄為其道也。
passages.en: I have heard that this Yi is a Mohist. Now Mo considers that in the regulation of funeral matters a spare simplicity should be the rule.

passages.zh: 夷子思以易天下，豈以為非是而不貴也？
passages.en: Yi thinks with Mo's doctrines to change the customs of the kingdom - how does he regard them as if they were wrong, and not honour them?

passages.zh: 然而夷子葬其親厚，則是以所賤事親也。」
passages.en: Notwithstanding his views, Yi buried his parents in a sumptuous manner, and so he served them in the way which his doctrines discountenance.'

passages.zh: 徐子以告夷子。
passages.en: The disciple Xu informed Yi of these remarks.

passages.zh: 夷子曰：「儒者之道，古之人『若保赤子』，此言何謂也？
passages.en: Yi said, 'Even according to the principles of the learned, we find that the ancients acted towards the people "as if they were watching over an infant." What does this expression mean?

passages.zh: 之則以為愛無差等，施由親始。」
passages.en: To me it sounds that we are to love all without difference of degree; but the manifestation of love must begin with our parents.'

passages.zh: 徐子以告孟子。
passages.en: Xu reported this reply to Mencius,

passages.zh: 孟子曰：「夫夷子，信以為人之親其兄之子為若親其鄰之赤子乎？
passages.en: who said, 'Now, does Yi really think that a man's affection for the child of his brother is merely like his affection for the infant of a neighbour?

passages.zh: 彼有取爾也。赤子匍匐將入井，非赤子之罪也。
passages.en: What is to be approved in that expression is simply this: that if an infant crawling about is likely to fall into a well, it is no crime in the infant.

passages.zh: 且天之生物也，使之一本，而夷子二本故也。
passages.en: Moreover, Heaven gives birth to creatures in such a way that they have one root, and Yi makes them to have two roots. This is the cause of his error.

passages.zh: 蓋上世嘗有不葬其親者。其親死，則舉而委之於壑。
passages.en: And, in the most ancient times, there were some who did not inter their parents. When their parents died, they took them up and threw them into some water-channel.

passages.zh: 他日過之，狐狸食之，蠅蚋姑嘬之。其顙有泚，睨而不視。
passages.en: Afterwards, when passing by them, they saw foxes and wild-cats devouring them, and flies and gnats biting at them. The perspiration started out upon their foreheads, and they looked away, unable to bear the sight.

passages.zh: 夫泚也，非為人泚，中心達於面目。
passages.en: It was not on account of other people that this perspiration flowed. The emotions of their hearts affected their faces and eyes,

passages.zh: 蓋歸反虆梩而掩之。
passages.en: and instantly they went home, and came back with baskets and spades and covered the bodies.

passages.zh: 掩之誠是也，則孝子仁人之掩其親，亦必有道矣。」
passages.en: If the covering them thus was indeed right, you may see that the filial son and virtuous man, in interring in a handsome manner their parents, act according to a proper rule.'

passages.zh: 徐子以告夷子。
passages.en: The disciple Xu informed Yi of what Mencius had said.

passages.zh: 夷子憮然為閒曰：「命之矣。」
passages.en: Yi was thoughtful for a short time, and then said, 'He has instructed me.'
